summary: Stark Sibling AU where everything is the same but their gender is swapped. Robb becomes Robyn, Sansa becomes Sanser (Samson?...
body:
Stark Sibling AU where everything is the same but their gender is swapped. Robb becomes Robyn, Sansa becomes Sanser (Samson? Sander?), Arya becomes Arry, Bran becomes Brandyn and Rickon becomes Ricka). 

Is male!Sansa still obsessed with love stories like in the songs or has he, as the heir of Winterfell, a bit less romantized idea about love? Arry can freely live out his love for sword fighting, archery and riding without having to worry about his needlework. What about Robb, Bran and Rickon? What changes for them? 

And when Robert comes to Winterfell, which of his children does he offer for a marriage to Ned? Still Joffrey but this time to Bran? Or Robb? Or maybe Myrcella for Sansa or Arya. Does Ned take Sansa to King’s Landing since he is the heir to Winterfell? Does he take Robb instead? Does Bran still climb as frequently as in canon or does Catelyn accept it less since Bran is a girl now? Does he even find Cersei and Jaime? And how does the fact that Jon is (apparently) Ned’s oldest son now his relationship with Catelyn?

body:
I was tagged by @redlektor thanks!!!

Rules : list the first lines of the last ten published stories. look to see if there is only patterns that you notice yourself, and see if anyone else notices any! Tag up to 10 friends. 

 Roommates

“Oh, God! Not another one,” Varys moaned the moment I opened his apartment door. He was half leaning out of his couch, staring at the red headed girl I brought home with me. He sighed at the sight of her and lifted up the remote control to turn America’s Top Model on louder.

“Really, Varys,” I chided, as I pressed my hand down on the small curve of Sansa’s back to lead her into the room. “That is no way to treat a guest.”

“Guest,” Varys said sarcastically, barely containing his smug. “Is that what you call them?”

Sansa’s cheeks went scarlet red, it was clear Varys was getting to her already. “I thought you said you were going out?” I said in an accusatory tone, while I leaned over the back of the couch to intimidate the slightly bald-headed man.

“Change of plans, my friend.”

“How about you change them again?”

Varys turned down the television before he turned to my date and I. “I’m afraid it doesn’t work that way. The two of you are more than welcome to go to her place.”

Roommates 2

I sauntered into the living room with a grey t-shirt and a light spring jacket when Varys looked me up and down with disapproval. “Oh no, that will never do,” he cooed, and motioned for me to go back into my bedroom and change.

“It’s fine,” I said through gritted teeth as I popped up the collar. “We won’t be that long anyways.”

“Yes, we will,” he rebutted as he followed me around the room.

“You might, but I will leave the first chance I get.”

Varys tutted and muttered, “You can try, old friend, but you won’t succeed.”

“Watch me.” I lifted my right foot on the seat of the chair to tie up my laces, ignoring the way Varys was leaning on the back of the seat watching me with those beady eyes of his. “You don’t think I can do it?”

“They don’t call her the Queen of Thorns for nothing.”

“It will work. You’ll see.”

“You bringing a date won’t help,” he added, as he dragged his finger along the top of the chair. “You know how much she loves to pry.”

The Devil’s Treachery

“Lord of Light, give me the courage and the wisdom to do as you bid. Help me, I beg of you, so that I may bring life back to this man’s bones. I have seen your visions. I have seen the things to come: death and destruction, fire and ice, and once they all die away only then will he appear.”

The bald-headed priest bowed his head, as he continued to knell on the floor. The fire blazed before him; white embers kindled in the blaze, while bright sparks of light flickered in the air. The priest sat still for a little while longer before he rose from the floor. The body was still there, Lord Baelish’s pale figure was laid out upon the table. His neck was severed; his eyes were shut. He smelt of death and decay. The priest laid a hand on the dead man’s chest, trailing his fingers down the silver scar that once cut the man in two. The priest shook his head and said, “I cannot do what you ask of me. This man has been gone for far too long.”

To the Stars and Back

“Computer, play me Man on the Moon by R.E.M.”

“Playing requested song,” said the automated voice, before the song blasted through unseen speakers overhead.

“Computer, open window panels. I want to see outside.”

My bedroom wall eased its way open, sliding back until the glass windows were revealed. I stepped closer and looked at the scenery with a wide-eyed expression. Will I ever get tired of this? A swirling cloud of red could be seen in deep space, blending in with a deep royal blue; a myriad of silver stars stretched out across the black expansiveness of space.

“Computer, how do you define beautiful?”

“Number one: Having qualities of beauty and is aesthetically pleasing to the eye. Number two: Generally pleasing to-”

“No, that’s not good enough,” I interjected. “If you could just see this view!” I pressed my hand against the glass and marveled at the infinite space in front of me.

To the Moon and Back

 Breathe.

My heart was beating at a tremendous pace, hammering out of my chest as I walked down the open hallway.

 Its not him- not really.

My Petyr would hobble with his trusty cane towards me, not swagger in front of me with a confident air. This new Petyr- this man who threw on a tarnished leather jacket while talking to Mariam was so very different from the man I loved. He brushed his curly bangs away from his face, half squinting at Mariam after he made a harmless joke. She laughed at him, covering her mouth as he leaned into her ear to whisper something sinful.

“Petyr!” she cried out and swatted him away like an irritating fly.

He bit down on his bottom lip, smirking at her with narrowed eyes. She shoved him away playfully and looked down the hall to see me approaching. “Oh,” she mouthed, and Petyr caught her shocked expression and his earnest gaze soon followed. His eyebrows raised in surprise, the lines around his face smoothed over as he stared at me with a pleased expression.

Its not him, I reminded myself, after he shoved his hands deep into his jeans pockets. He’s too young for one thing, and too…

Proven Wrong

I wandered around the edges of the castle, letting my fingers slide against the slick wet bricks that was still damp from the morning rain. I was so high up on this eminence, it was enough for me to see the rolling hills and the tree tops of the forbidden forest.

I’m home, I thought, as I watched the trees sway in the soft willowing wind.  The wind carried voices as well, hundreds of cries could be heard as children continued to flow out of the train station. In a matter of hours, a few hundred first-year students would take their first few steps up the mountainous terrain which would inevitably lead to Hogwarts.

I heard a cry of phoenix above my head, it flashed through the gunmetal sky like a bright comet of fire. There was magic here, it could be felt everywhere. Perhaps, that’s why I’m so happy to be back home, or that’s what I tried to convince myself as I skipped down the last set of stairs.

Hogwarts had been closed for over a year; it was for our own safety, or at least that is what the Headmaster had claimed when he sent out a letter to all the students. But I knew the true reason why no student could trespass these large stony walls until now. There was a danger which lurked in the shadows, it slithers through the walls, griped at our throats when we weren’t looking.

The Mockingbird’s Song

The sound of heavy footfalls outside my door released me from my cheerless solitude. A key pierced through the golden lock and then erupted, before my door swung open to allow a shadow to slip through. In the candlelight, Lord Baelish’s tired, forlorn face was revealed; deep lines etched beneath his grey-green eyes as he stared back at me.

“I’m not going to hurt you, sweetling,” he whispered, as he sat down at the edge of my bed. His fingers ran through my disheveled sheets, as he murmured, “I imagine you are growing quite lonely by now. Locked away in your room for days… without a soul to speak too. But, I want you to know that I am your friend, and I only want what’s best for you.”

Petyr leaned himself further back, until the bed gave way to his additional weight with a serious of creaks and groans. Petyr ignored them, he simply laid his hand close to my own and continued, “At this very moment, the Queen is offering a lordship for the price of your head. Your husband is rotting away in some prison cell awaiting his execution. But you, my dear, are sailing away from harm’s way undetected by Lannister spies, but that all could change if I let you freely walk around my ship alone, so you must understand the reason I am keeping you locked away in this room.”

The Strange Tales of Doctor Strange

This is a bad idea, I thought, as I ducked into an alleyway and began to jog down the length of it. I’m such a stupid girl, and I never learn.

There was nothing on me, no purse, no phone, only a skimpy sky-blue dress that would undoubtedly attract unwanted attention. I’m almost there, I told myself, as I picked up the pace despite the towering heels I was in. The cold air rushed past me, the streets of New York was unusually quiet tonight. A bad sign, I rather be lost in a rush of commotion than be lost in this dark alley looking for the bar that I left not to long ago.

I think its here, I thought, and turned the corner into a busy street where people were coming and going as they please. A typical Friday night, I thought, and jay-crossed across the street to the lit-up tavern across the road. The Temple was illuminated with red letters, and the black and gold doors were silently entreating me to open it. Here goes nothing, I thought, and swung open the door to walk in.

A few people looked over the brim of their cup to ogle at me, a red-headed girl in a strapless dress was an unusual sight, even in New York. I ignored their stares and took a step forward, intent on having a word with the bartender my friends and I spoke to not to long ago.

“Excuse me…” my voice trailed away when a dark-haired man with silver haired temples.

Falling Down the Rabbit’s Hole

This wasn’t supposed to happen. I should have never been called in to teach, but here I am standing in front of a classroom with nothing but my wits to sustain me.

“Economics!” I exclaimed, a thrill rang through my voice as I uttered the word. “It is the foundation of our society, the building block for all businesses. To understand it, is to succeed- not only in your professional life, but in your personal one as well.”

A loud boom resounded throughout the room as a student let the door slam behind her. She offered me a sheepish grin, before she wandered throughout the room in search of a seat.

“There’s one here,” I remarked, while pointing out an empty chair in front of me. She was so nervous, the poor thing, she almost tip-toed towards her seat; her cheeks were flushed a crimson red, an amusing shade that nearly rivaled her bright auburn hair. Her pale blue eyes were unwilling to look into my own. Was she ashamed or just scared to lock her eyes with mine, I wondered. I’ll probably never know the answer to that question, for she had every intention to stare down at her impeccably white shoes until I looked away from her.

Patterns: I tend to open up a chapter with dialogue or the character’s inner thoughts. I also ease my way into the storyline, before I put in the real drama and angst. I guess this is the smooth, flat part of the rollercoaster ride before I take you on a ride. Enjoy the climb.

I think everyone has been tagged but I really want to see @quoyan11 and @clarissa-dn38416

 Roommates

“Oh, God! Not another one,” Varys moaned the moment I opened his apartment door. He was half leaning out of his couch, staring at the red headed girl I brought home with me. He sighed at the sight of her and lifted up the remote control to turn America’s Top Model on louder.

“Really, Varys,” I chided, as I pressed my hand down on the small curve of Sansa’s back to lead her into the room. “That is no way to treat a guest.”

“Guest,” Varys said sarcastically, barely containing his smug. “Is that what you call them?”

Sansa’s cheeks went scarlet red, it was clear Varys was getting to her already. “I thought you said you were going out?” I said in an accusatory tone, while I leaned over the back of the couch to intimidate the slightly bald-headed man.

“Change of plans, my friend.”

“How about you change them again?”

Varys turned down the television before he turned to my date and I. “I’m afraid it doesn’t work that way. The two of you are more than welcome to go to her place.”

Roommates 2

I sauntered into the living room with a grey t-shirt and a light spring jacket when Varys looked me up and down with disapproval. “Oh no, that will never do,” he cooed, and motioned for me to go back into my bedroom and change.

“It’s fine,” I said through gritted teeth as I popped up the collar. “We won’t be that long anyways.”

“Yes, we will,” he rebutted as he followed me around the room.

“You might, but I will leave the first chance I get.”

Varys tutted and muttered, “You can try, old friend, but you won’t succeed.”

“Watch me.” I lifted my right foot on the seat of the chair to tie up my laces, ignoring the way Varys was leaning on the back of the seat watching me with those beady eyes of his. “You don’t think I can do it?”

“They don’t call her the Queen of Thorns for nothing.”

“It will work. You’ll see.”

“You bringing a date won’t help,” he added, as he dragged his finger along the top of the chair. “You know how much she loves to pry.”

The Devil’s Treachery

“Lord of Light, give me the courage and the wisdom to do as you bid. Help me, I beg of you, so that I may bring life back to this man’s bones. I have seen your visions. I have seen the things to come: death and destruction, fire and ice, and once they all die away only then will he appear.”

The bald-headed priest bowed his head, as he continued to knell on the floor. The fire blazed before him; white embers kindled in the blaze, while bright sparks of light flickered in the air. The priest sat still for a little while longer before he rose from the floor. The body was still there, Lord Baelish’s pale figure was laid out upon the table. His neck was severed; his eyes were shut. He smelt of death and decay. The priest laid a hand on the dead man’s chest, trailing his fingers down the silver scar that once cut the man in two. The priest shook his head and said, “I cannot do what you ask of me. This man has been gone for far too long.”

To the Stars and Back

“Computer, play me Man on the Moon by R.E.M.”

“Playing requested song,” said the automated voice, before the song blasted through unseen speakers overhead.

“Computer, open window panels. I want to see outside.”

My bedroom wall eased its way open, sliding back until the glass windows were revealed. I stepped closer and looked at the scenery with a wide-eyed expression. Will I ever get tired of this? A swirling cloud of red could be seen in deep space, blending in with a deep royal blue; a myriad of silver stars stretched out across the black expansiveness of space.

“Computer, how do you define beautiful?”

“Number one: Having qualities of beauty and is aesthetically pleasing to the eye. Number two: Generally pleasing to-”

“No, that’s not good enough,” I interjected. “If you could just see this view!” I pressed my hand against the glass and marveled at the infinite space in front of me.

To the Moon and Back

 Breathe.

My heart was beating at a tremendous pace, hammering out of my chest as I walked down the open hallway.

 Its not him- not really.

My Petyr would hobble with his trusty cane towards me, not swagger in front of me with a confident air. This new Petyr- this man who threw on a tarnished leather jacket while talking to Mariam was so very different from the man I loved. He brushed his curly bangs away from his face, half squinting at Mariam after he made a harmless joke. She laughed at him, covering her mouth as he leaned into her ear to whisper something sinful.

“Petyr!” she cried out and swatted him away like an irritating fly.

He bit down on his bottom lip, smirking at her with narrowed eyes. She shoved him away playfully and looked down the hall to see me approaching. “Oh,” she mouthed, and Petyr caught her shocked expression and his earnest gaze soon followed. His eyebrows raised in surprise, the lines around his face smoothed over as he stared at me with a pleased expression.

Its not him, I reminded myself, after he shoved his hands deep into his jeans pockets. He’s too young for one thing, and too…

Proven Wrong

I wandered around the edges of the castle, letting my fingers slide against the slick wet bricks that was still damp from the morning rain. I was so high up on this eminence, it was enough for me to see the rolling hills and the tree tops of the forbidden forest.

I’m home, I thought, as I watched the trees sway in the soft willowing wind.  The wind carried voices as well, hundreds of cries could be heard as children continued to flow out of the train station. In a matter of hours, a few hundred first-year students would take their first few steps up the mountainous terrain which would inevitably lead to Hogwarts.

I heard a cry of phoenix above my head, it flashed through the gunmetal sky like a bright comet of fire. There was magic here, it could be felt everywhere. Perhaps, that’s why I’m so happy to be back home, or that’s what I tried to convince myself as I skipped down the last set of stairs.

Hogwarts had been closed for over a year; it was for our own safety, or at least that is what the Headmaster had claimed when he sent out a letter to all the students. But I knew the true reason why no student could trespass these large stony walls until now. There was a danger which lurked in the shadows, it slithers through the walls, griped at our throats when we weren’t looking.

The Mockingbird’s Song

The sound of heavy footfalls outside my door released me from my cheerless solitude. A key pierced through the golden lock and then erupted, before my door swung open to allow a shadow to slip through. In the candlelight, Lord Baelish’s tired, forlorn face was revealed; deep lines etched beneath his grey-green eyes as he stared back at me.

“I’m not going to hurt you, sweetling,” he whispered, as he sat down at the edge of my bed. His fingers ran through my disheveled sheets, as he murmured, “I imagine you are growing quite lonely by now. Locked away in your room for days… without a soul to speak too. But, I want you to know that I am your friend, and I only want what’s best for you.”

Petyr leaned himself further back, until the bed gave way to his additional weight with a serious of creaks and groans. Petyr ignored them, he simply laid his hand close to my own and continued, “At this very moment, the Queen is offering a lordship for the price of your head. Your husband is rotting away in some prison cell awaiting his execution. But you, my dear, are sailing away from harm’s way undetected by Lannister spies, but that all could change if I let you freely walk around my ship alone, so you must understand the reason I am keeping you locked away in this room.”

The Strange Tales of Doctor Strange

This is a bad idea, I thought, as I ducked into an alleyway and began to jog down the length of it. I’m such a stupid girl, and I never learn.

There was nothing on me, no purse, no phone, only a skimpy sky-blue dress that would undoubtedly attract unwanted attention. I’m almost there, I told myself, as I picked up the pace despite the towering heels I was in. The cold air rushed past me, the streets of New York was unusually quiet tonight. A bad sign, I rather be lost in a rush of commotion than be lost in this dark alley looking for the bar that I left not to long ago.

I think its here, I thought, and turned the corner into a busy street where people were coming and going as they please. A typical Friday night, I thought, and jay-crossed across the street to the lit-up tavern across the road. The Temple was illuminated with red letters, and the black and gold doors were silently entreating me to open it. Here goes nothing, I thought, and swung open the door to walk in.

A few people looked over the brim of their cup to ogle at me, a red-headed girl in a strapless dress was an unusual sight, even in New York. I ignored their stares and took a step forward, intent on having a word with the bartender my friends and I spoke to not to long ago.

“Excuse me…” my voice trailed away when a dark-haired man with silver haired temples.

Falling Down the Rabbit’s Hole

This wasn’t supposed to happen. I should have never been called in to teach, but here I am standing in front of a classroom with nothing but my wits to sustain me.

“Economics!” I exclaimed, a thrill rang through my voice as I uttered the word. “It is the foundation of our society, the building block for all businesses. To understand it, is to succeed- not only in your professional life, but in your personal one as well.”

A loud boom resounded throughout the room as a student let the door slam behind her. She offered me a sheepish grin, before she wandered throughout the room in search of a seat.

“There’s one here,” I remarked, while pointing out an empty chair in front of me. She was so nervous, the poor thing, she almost tip-toed towards her seat; her cheeks were flushed a crimson red, an amusing shade that nearly rivaled her bright auburn hair. Her pale blue eyes were unwilling to look into my own. Was she ashamed or just scared to lock her eyes with mine, I wondered. I’ll probably never know the answer to that question, for she had every intention to stare down at her impeccably white shoes until I looked away from her.

Patterns: I tend to open up a chapter with dialogue or the character’s inner thoughts. I also ease my way into the storyline, before I put in the real drama and angst. I guess this is the smooth, flat part of the rollercoaster ride before I take you on a ride. Enjoy the climb.

I think everyone has been tagged but I really want to see @quoyan11 and @clarissa-dn38416

tags: this is why i love sansa stark
sansa is the one to watch
summary: I sometimes feel like there’s this stigma on how much you can love/stan Sansa. Like if you like Sansa too much you’re “clearly...
body:
I sometimes feel like there’s this stigma on how much you can love/stan Sansa. Like if you like Sansa too much you’re “clearly biased” or you have to prove that you’re not just a Sansa stan or that you loved another character first before you liked Sansa. But honestly FUCK THAT NOISE! As a person who came late to the Game of Thrones world and binged watched seasons 1-6 a year before season 7, I wasn’t really impressed with the show. Don’t get me wrong, I liked it and thought the show had some great moments but it didn’t live up to the hype for me and there were definitely points in the show that were boring. After season 6, the only character that truly left me blown away was Sansa Stark. Her character arc was incredible and left a deep impression on me and she easily became one of the best female characters on television. Everything about her story seemed so real and relatable and her journey has been one of beauty and strength.


Sansa Stark is one of the main reasons I decided to watch season 7! I wasn’t that invested in the show but my love for Sansa made me invested. She is a remarkable, beautifully layered character and quite frankly one of if not the best character on the show! I don’t have to justify or down play why I love her because her journey speaks for itself!

Everyone has their faves, mine just happens to be Sansa. If you don’t see the beauty in her journey and her value as a character that’s on you! One thing I know for sure is that you’re not going to put Sansa Stark or her fans in a corner! Best believe Sansa Stark, the character who is religiously underrated, will rise in season 8 and those who slept on her will be shocked!

summary: Why is it that the current mentors of the young Starks (LF, The Faceless Men and Bloodraven), the ones meant to train them for...
question: Why is it that the current mentors of the young Starks (LF, The Faceless Men and Bloodraven), the ones meant to train them for their part in the endgame and beyond, are all shitty in some way? Their goals range from unjust at best to devastating at worst.
answer:
To be fair, Bloodraven’s on the right side of things, it’s just that his moral supervision of the child he’s training up to serious supernatural power is severely lacking. Uncle Ben he is not.

The answer, though, is conflict. 

If Littlefinger really did see Sansa as a daughter and only as a daughter, if he was sincere in his love for her and Catelyn, where’s Sansa’s internal conflict? Everything’s external: will Sansa regain Winterfell? Will she go North in time to meaningfully aid her family? She never has to ask herself who she is and who she wants to be. Ditto Arya, though it’s harder to see how she could learn those particular skills from morally above-board sources. Uh, say she was learning fighting from some old soldiers and moonlighting with mummers, go with that. If she did that, she never has to ask herself who she is and who she wants to be, either, and again the conflict would be coming only from external factors. And Bran - without going the wrong way, his powers turn into a supernatural slugfest, rather than an examination of the responsibility that comes with that power.

body:
Sansa: I’m easy-going.

Robb: I once saw you use a ruler to measure another ruler.

Sansa: It was off by half a centimeter. It should never have been in circulation.

summary: Kate Bishop/Dick Grayson. Or if you're not a BatFamily person, Kate Bishop/Sansa Stark.
question: Kate Bishop/Dick Grayson. Or if you're not a BatFamily person, Kate Bishop/Sansa Stark.
answer:
damn!!! u really Went There!!!!

so anyway in general i have feelings about marvel characters accidentally winding up in Westeros because why not but part of me thinks Kate/Sansa works better in the medieval version of Kate? The one that’s literally out there being Robin Hood

so like. 

Hawkeye is the terror of the Lannister army. she and her band of merry men are fast, attacking troops and stealing things–weapons, food, coin–and gone before anyone is the wiser. Nobody knows what she looks like, or that she’s a she.

There’s just a story, of a man who steals from the rich and gives that to those the army has taken from. A man who stands between the army and the smallfolk they would harm, with a bow and arrows and a purple cloak.

Sansa knows better than to put stock in such tales, to daydream about handsome knights, but the story takes root in her mind and offers her–not comfort, exactly, but a small happiness. That someone is out there, doing something. It makes Sansa envious. 

And then one night, as they are making their way from the Vale to…where, Sansa isn’t sure, a cry goes up that someone has killed Littlefinger. 

The next thing Sansa knows there is a hulking knight collapsed in a pile in her tent, groaning and–from what Sansa can tell–bleeding.

“Are you Hawkeye?” Sansa whispers.

The knight groans, and removes his helmet–

And reveals one of the loveliest women Sansa has ever seen. Familiar, too, Sansa recalls seeing her–she’s that man, Derek Bishop’s daughter. A fickle bannerman of the north.

“Are you Hawkeye?” Sansa asks again, louder.

“I’ll be dead if you say that again,” the woman groans. She has a sword at her side, a bow across her back, and a sack that looks to be full of the valuables Littlefinger kept in his tent. 

And Sansa–well, she knows a few things about hiding who you are, and she makes quick work of divesting the woman of her armor. Sansa hides the armor, the weapons, the gold in her trunks, under her bed, wherever she can manage and shoves the lady-turned-bandit into a dress. It’s too big for her, of course, she’s not nearly as tall as Sansa, but it’s enough, and Sansa manages to convince the knights who come inquiring that Hawkeye is a maid who was frightened of all the commotion.

(in a week or so, when Hawkeye is healed enough to leave, Sansa will help her back into her armor, and just before she puts her helmet back on, she will whisper “My name is not Alayne Stone–it’s Sansa Stark,” into Hawkeye’s ear. 

“My name is Kate,” she will say, and then Sansa will press a kiss to her lips. 

It’s a nice kiss. The nicest Sansa’s ever had, soft and sweet. Sansa tangles her fingers in Kate’s long dark hair.

“I’ll come back to you,” Kate promises, breathless.

And she does.)

(also, GoT!Sansa and ASoIaF!Sansa are really different people…I went more with a book!sansa here, though I think there’s a lot of interesting stuff to be said about how show!Sansa and Kate would bond)
